name: PythonRunProcessor
input:
import os
base_dir = "/tmp/pragmatics/bash-find-dont-contain"
os.makedirs(base_dir, exist_ok=True)
open(base_dir + "/hello", "w").write("this is a test")
open(base_dir + "/there", "w").write("test this ASDF")
open(base_dir + "/this", "w").write("whatever thing")
open(base_dir + "/asdf", "w").write("zzzthing")
open(base_dir + "/lower", "w").write("test this asdf")

name: AnthropicModel

input.content: In bash list all files in /tmp/pragmatics/bash-find-dont-contain that don't contain asdf in the contents (case-ignore)

output:
To list all files in the `/tmp/pragmatics/bash-find-dont-contain` directory that don't contain the string "asdf" in their contents (case-insensitive), you can use the following bash command:

```bash
find /tmp/pragmatics/bash-find-dont-contain -type f -exec grep -iL "asdf" {} +
```

Here's what each part of the command does:

- `find /tmp/pragmatics/bash-find-dont-contain`: This specifies the directory where the search should start.
- `-type f`: This option restricts the search to only regular files (excluding directories, symlinks, etc.).
- `-exec grep -iL "asdf" {} +`: This executes the `grep` command on each file found by `find`.
  - `-i`: This option makes the search case-insensitive.
  - `-L`: This option inverts the match, so it only prints the names of files that don't contain the specified pattern.
  - `"asdf"`: This is the pattern to search for (the string "asdf").
  - `{}`: This represents the current file being processed by `find`.
  - `+`: This terminator allows `find` to pass multiple files to `grep` at once, improving performance compared to executing `grep` separately for each file.

The command will output the names of all files in the `/tmp/pragmatics/bash-find-dont-contain` directory that don't contain the string "asdf" (case-insensitive) in their contents.

```bash
find /tmp/pragmatics/bash-find-dont-contain -type f -exec grep -iL "asdf" {} +
```

Here's what each part of the command does:

- `find /tmp/pragmatics/bash-find-dont-contain`: This specifies the directory where the search should start.
- `-type f`: This option restricts the search to only regular files (excluding directories, symlinks, etc.).
- `-exec grep -iL "asdf" {} +`: This executes the `grep` command on each file found by `find`.
  - `-i`: This option makes the search case-insensitive.
  - `-L`: This option inverts the match, so it only prints the names of files that don't contain the specified pattern.
  - `"asdf"`: This is the pattern to search for (the string "asdf").
  - `{}`: This represents the current file being processed by `find`.
  - `+`: This terminator allows `find` to pass multiple files to `grep` at once, improving performance compared to executing `grep` separately for each file.

The command will output the names of all files in the `/tmp/pragmatics/bash-find-dont-contain` directory that don't contain the string "asdf" (case-insensitive) in their contents.
